commentBody:
No rebuses.
No missing letters.
No theme.

So is this puzzle CHIC or SWILL?

Deb,
Re: 5D explanation 
It's not another spelling. As per the clue, the LEASER makes payments to the lessor.

This was a fine Friday puzzle for me, tougher than usual, I am always happy to say (if it's true).

The phrase "Who am I TO question?" does not ring a bell with me, since I have never read or heard that phrase without some more words afterwards. And I dunno, claiming that PAH means "Hogwash!" seems going out on a limb here. (I associate "pah" with something French people often say, as if to pronounce "pah" but with no vowel sound, just an exhalation. And if I had to translate it, I'd say it means "Gee, I don't know about that," not as strong as "Hogwash!".)

In the entire corpus of Icelandic literature, there are only two Eddas. The so-called Elder Edda is a 16th-century anthology of short poems dating back to the 9th century; the Younger Edda is a poetic  — a manual for would-be poets — written by Snorri Sturluson ca. 1200 AD. Obviously, "edda" is not a genre. A saga is a lengthy prose narrative not unlike a novel. A saga is not an edda and vice versa.

My INNERGEEK came out in this one. I enjoyed the plethora of misdirects in the clues, especially those for DELETEDSCENES and SPEEDGUN.  It took me a bit to work out the SE corner, which actually opened up for me when I recalled that A. Q. I. was air quality index, which gave me EPA, which gave me ELENA and so on.  No typos to search out tonight made for a satisfying ending.
Fun, witty cluing. Had HELD NERVE before HELD SERVE and that tripped me up for a while.
Some easy spots but some harder ones, and a lot of very clever clues—CREASED, SPEEDGUN, HATEWATCJ, OEUVRE, DELETEDSCENES, HELDSERVE all stellar in my opinion. I enjoyed it!
49A [In need of an evening out] is a real knee-slapper.
We’ve been saying OEUVRE around the house lately, just to sound fancy. I had no idea how to spell it.
Commenting on the Mini Puzzle today. Joel’s tongue twitter clue made me stop,think,laugh. Fun one today. Thanks Joel F.
Completed with no shade at all! LOVED completing this one.

The INNERGEEK in me strenuously objects to called the pre-title card that reads "A long time ago, in a galaxy far far away..." the prologue. I can't imagine calling anything other than the opening scrawled that follows the title the prologue.

Also, almost got screwed up because I assumed an animal that began with NE in a crossword had to be a NENE. Took a while to find that mistake, but I WEASELED my way out in the end
Wow. Some amazing clueing. 49A has to be in the running for clue by of the year.
My first word had a fair bit of alone time, LENDER for LEASER was a bit of a stumble, but I eventually held serve and came in well under my Friday average.

I really enjoyed all the clever misdirects in the clues.  The answer to “In need of an evening out?” especially tickled my funny bone.  Or maybe it was just the dopamine rush of flying through the grid after struggling mightily to get a toehold.

I for one found this puzzle to be quite enjoyable.  

Gave me plenty of resistance, but never left me stuck, at least not for very long.

I just loved several clue/answer pairs.  HELDSERVE is ingenious, and CREASED was beautiful, and though I've never heard of a BROHUG, it certainly made sense.

And I think I learned how to spell OEUVRE here, which as I understand it is Spanish for "eggs".**








**I don't really, but I thought it was kind of funny.  I couldn't actually remember the Spanish word, but it's in the same ball park, letter-wise.

I spent over 5 minutes searching for my error. I had DELETEs SCENES and couldn’t figure out what I had wrong.  🤦🏼‍♀️ D’OH. Otherwise I felt like I was on Larry’s wavelength through the entire puzzle. So close to a PB if not for that error. Really clever clueing for this one. 👍🏼👍🏼 two thumbs up
“Didn't get broken” at 32D was impossible for me (HELDSERVE), especially combined with "Hogwash!" at 31A (PAH).

Re 10D: Yah, try telling that to mine. He considers his job to be done once they've been delivered alive to me to hang out.

(Unfortunately, the most recent one is too clever for the humane trap and also talkative, keeping me up at all hours. This has been going on for well over a week.)

Excellent puzzle. Tough but fair.

The clue for DELETEDSCENES is the best in a long time. 

10/10.
Great clues, great fun.
My favorite Friday puzzle since March 21

Very enjoyable clueing here. I particularly liked 15A [Stream with a lot of shade?] HATE WATCH and 33A [Takes in the trash?] DELETED SCENES. With the latter, it took me a bit to realize that “takes” was not a verb. 

I lost a little time with 22A FERRETS, assuming that the answer would be another bird species. Falcon worked so well (until it didn’t).

Speaking of ferrets — if you’re old enough to remember Rudy Giuliani, and you’ve never heard his ferret rant, it’s worth looking for on YouTube. 

Thanks for the fun, Mr. Snyder!

I got lucky. No incorrect cells. 
Solved very quickly given how much I struggled. 
Very sold Friday. 

I haven’t seen anyone explain 
“Call at the table?”. SEE. 

Help.
Smart meaning chic is British usage. It would be considered uncomfortably pretentious to use 'smart' for 'chic' in the good ol' US of A.

I just finished the Thursday puzzle and, as is my wont, toddled over to Wordplay to be amused and enlightened.  My machine says there are over 800 comments. 
Has my machine lost its mind? Are you all still over there? Did someone reprint the Lincoln-Douglass debates paragraph by paragraph? Try to explain US foreign policy? Settle the plural of OCTOPXXX? Before I plunge in, I'd love a clue.

I had “held nerve” instead of HELD SERVE as I know nothing about tennis and was thinking, darkly, of a hostage scenario or some sort of situation when one might break.

Liked the crossing of FERRETS and WEASELED.

Happy weekend to all~
Very satisfying crossword.  Loved “Takes in the trash”!

SE corner killed my gold star streak. I just couldn't get OEUVRE and CREASED.

PAH! Hogwash!

This was a great puzzle, worthy of a Friday.  I love it when the first couple of words you think of when you read a clue don't fit, so you have to work around that word and maybe snag a couple of letters on intersecting clues, and then the answer reveals itself and it makes total sense.

Nice to see the old EDDA again—it's been a while.  All in all, an entertaining puzzle, with a few clues that had me stalled, e.g., "In need of any evening out?"  That one had my brow CREASED, because I am so in need of one.
.  
Thank you, Larry.  Just tricky enough for a Friday.

A nice solid Friday that took some time for me to make my way through. Some excellent cluing, as has been mentioned previously. My favorites were 33A and 32D, the latter being my last fill, as I finally realized, "Oh, that's tennis!" and entered the last letters. Also liked the clues for 27D and 49A.

Thanks, Larry!

In Psychology, it is often said that the brain cannot think in negatives.

For 41-Across I had _ _ M P S and was certain that it is TEMPS.

Take that, Science.

The SE corner was much harder for me than the rest of the puzzle - I looked up CIPRO (how was I supposed to know *that*?) but I still struggled even though I correctly guessed the cruelly clued EPA, and ELENA was a gimme (I haven't read anything of hers but I've seen reviews in The Guardian - which is how I knew I wouldn't probably enjoy her oeuvre). Speaking of OEUVRE - I wanted some version of OpUs(__???) there. My mind just won't come to terms with the spelling of the French word. In Polish we just use our own term for it - twórczość. That's a spelling I get 🤣. (Tworzyć means to create. Twór [tvoor] is the result of creation. Twórca [tvoortsa] is one who creates, and Stwórca is one of the terms for Christian god: a non-divine creator would never be called stwórca)

The "evening out" clue was kinda brilliant, but I only understood it after crosses revealed the answer. I also only got the "broken" clue once I was only missing a single letter from the solution. Doh. I actually watch tennis!

Elsewhere I had to look up the crossing of the network and mascot. I suppose MR RED was gettable when you already had _RRED there, but I only remembered AbC as an American tv channel (how many Polish networks do *you* know or how many would you remember a month or two after I told you their names?). BRRED looked weird and I just couldn't be bothered to deal with an annoying crossing of trivia, so in stead of dealing with it on my own I asked google for help.
Good puzzle. SE was tough. Not sure why.

"I want to read every single one of that author's works!"
"You're such an oeuvre-achiever."

(But what a novel idea!)

Initial response to 49A: ME!!!!!

Later, more rational response: “Although it’s still Thursday, it’s unlikely that the Friday puzzle has five exclamation points in it.”

I was onto the lovely "evening out" clue having seen similar in cryptic crosswords in the UK.
"Some evening TV programme (8)" for AVENGERS is a great example that came to mind.
Very nice puzzle overall, thanks Larry!
time for my end-of-week quibble:  "cipro" is an abbreviation.  the name of the antibiotic is "ciprofloxacin."  that abbreviated fill was required should have been indicated or implied in the clue.
49A was absolutely brilliant!

Lots of great cluing here.  

Some favorites:

 [The works?] for OEUVRE, [Takes in the trash?] for DELETED SCENES  and of course, [In need of an evening out?] for CREASED.  

I checked xwordinfo to see if that clue for CREASED had ever been used before, and it's a debut.  The only other clue that was a misdirect was [Iron-deficient?].

The loud music the crossword is finished is very disturbing. Even when I he phone is on silent mode the loud music is difficult to quite. 
Also it's too American. The clues and the whole crossword is made for American players only.

Scuppered somewhat by the slang and brands, and how to pronounce MRRED..... And HATE WATCH is what some people do? ALONE TIME? EGO SURF? BANANA skin, not peel!

And no, I've never used a drive-through eatery, I've rarely even seen one!

However, cleverly clued  crossword, as others have pointed out. Seems a good one for a Friday.
Now that was my kind of crossword puzzle! Enjoyed immensely. Nice job,
SE was tough..my brain just couldn't read evening as a verb...but still half the time to solve of yesterday's puzzle.

This was a wow, with spark in answer, sweet resistance bringing sweet reward, clues whose answers couldn’t be immediately slapped down, and clues brimming with wordplay.

I’ll focus on that last point, as wordplay hits my happy button.  Today’s puzzle had it all:
•	Simple one-trick-pony wordplay, such as [Didn’t get broken] for HELD SERVE.  “Oh, *that* kind of ‘broken’!” Hah!
•	Double play, as with [Takes in the trash?] for DELETED SCENES. “Oh, noun-‘takes’, not verb-‘takes’, not to mention a new meaning for the full phrase ‘takes in the trash’”.  Mwah!
•	World-class wordplay – [In need of an evening out?] for CREASED.  Playing on “evening”, playing on “evening out”, playing on “in need of an evening out”, which brings up loneliness, perhaps, or being cocooned for too long, and deftly misdirects the mind from the actual meaning of this clue.  OMG!  Clue jackpot!  Deep bow.  

You wowed me, Larry, with a satisfying solve flecked with a fiesta of humor and play.  Thank you, sir, and more please!

Tough to follow a Lewis post, so I'll just say this was a good puzzle, hard but not killer hard, and I enjoyed it.

Holds the line, takes in the trash, and evening out were all top notch stuff.  This was a good time.

And it continues the somewhat exasperating trend of making the upper left the hardest part of the puzzle.  :(
I can’t get over how good the clueing is in this one.  Delightful solve.  Well done, Larry Snyder!

Typical tough Friday for me, but ended up being an enjoyable workout, with more than a few things finally dawning on me with some crosses. Puzzle find today was inspired by 25a (ALGORE). A Sunday from January 19, 1997 by B. Klahn with the title: "Presidential Punditry." Clue and answer that got me there: "Mathematical rules governing the Vice President's macarena?" ALGORERHYTHMS And some other theme answers: CHELSEAGRAMMAR DIRECTLYTOYALE DISSEDHILLARY And there were a couple of others. Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/19/1997&g=78&d=A I'm done. ...

Is there a word for clues that end with comma-qualifier?
For example:
, say
, in a way
, maybe
, of sorts

Those put me in a bad mood, but reading all the positive comments here makes me think that I'm just not experienced enough to appreciate it. I still don't think "speed gun" and "ego surf" are actual things. :P

Are folks just worn out from Commenting on yesterday's puzzle?  Because there were 844 there when I was up around 2 a.m. for the Spelling Bee.  Woof!

In "Own Worst Enemy" category, I have 21A, where I failed to cross the T and nearly had a stroke trying to make that i work.

Nice, au courant puzzle.  Instructional, even.
I am left with several questions:
Do FERRETS actually gather in groups?
Is IRONING actually considered "evening out"??
Why didn't I know precisely how to spell OEUVRE???  Nearly had OEUF on my face.

Great puzzle! Added OUEVRE to my lexicon, and the fact that ferrets travel in businesses to my bank of trivia. 

I am substantially over average every day this week and am anticipating a blank grid tomorrow after my first across and down passes if the pattern holds. 

Bring it on, NYT.

I was working on a puzzle from the archives today, from July 17, 2025. In the comments, a lot of people really liked this puzzle. But there was also a heated discussion started by a puzzler complaining that other people complained that the puzzles in general were too easy. That commenter stated something about having high blood pressure from those kind of comments and a long debate ensued re: are puzzles too easy? 

Well, I just started back doing puzzles after years and years not doing them, so I don't think they're too easy. But I have a question: why not bring back the "Double Crostics" (or "Acrostics") for those who want more challenges??

This was hard. Really hard. Not for beginners. Didn't finish it.

Didn't love it, but looks like others did.
If only we had listened to Al Gore ...
Took 14% longer than average.  Crunchy clues all around, but the southeast corner was the last to fall. Solid Friday fare.

I was going smoothly, making good Friday progress, until I hit the wall in the SE.  OUCH! 
Especially annoying because BANANA PEEL, SPEED GUN, EPA, and ELENA were all gimmes for me.
I didn't know CIPRO (I'm sure I'm not alone in that!), and I had GRasPED for "Put together".
And that got me from seeing the beautiful (but tricky!) combo of OEUVRE and CREASED for the longest time.

Favorite clue:  "Takes in the trash?"  Normally I take the trash OUT.  I don't need more trash in my ABODE.

OOF!  I've got a headache now.
I think I'll lie down.

I confidently entered LESSOR at an early point.  Which meant that the only word that could fit 22A was CARROTS.  But it’s not a galaxy CAR CAR away.  I was delighted to find out about FERRETS when I gave up on LESSOR and completed the NW corner, finishing my solve.

Who AM I to question how you spend your ALONE TIME? If you want to HATEWATCH the MEGHAN and Harry show, be my guest.

Great cluing today, but apparently I've been reading "Bowdlerize" wrong my whole life. I honestly thought it meant to parody something, a la Weird Al Yankovich. TIL there was a Dr. Bowdler who released CENSORed versions of Shakespeare.

Great Friday . I nominate the " evening out " - ie Creased - for clue of the year . Can anyone help me with the origin of Bowdlerize ??
I got CENSOR from the crosses but never heard of that word. 
TGIF .
Oh you clue for 33A! You plural noun masquerading as a present tense verb! You fooled me until almost the end.

Not bad, not bad at all. Very Friday-ish, but I made it through. 

Better than I did with the wet walnuts, which I made yesterday. @Helen Wright, as I said a few days ago, I am providing it for our historical societies' program with President and Mrs. Madison tomorrow. 

Well, I mixed the brown sugar, honey, vanilla, pinch of salt all together in the pan, kept an eye on it, waiting for it to boil, and turned my back for one tiny second. 

All who cook will know what happened then. 

My husband helped me cleanup the overflow mess. (He should; he volunteered me for this.) And I had to make another. 1/2 recipe to make up for it. Tastes good, regardless, and it's chilling in the fridge. We'll see how it goes over tomorrow.

Happy Friday, fellow solvers!

Bravo Mr Snyder!
I appreciated your fun and tricky clues and I found your note on your order of operations very interesting. 
Alea iacta est reminded me of a malaphor, a funny unintentional mixing of metaphors, by character in an old British TV drama. “The die has been burnt, the bridge has been cast, my friend!”
Perhaps an idea for a puzzle theme?

Very nice! I was wayyy ahead of my average until... the southeast corner. Not being a tennis player meant blind guesses until I got the music. Came here to be schooled. Bravo! Now off to the Friday morning work buffet....

One more late puzzle find. A Sunday from November 22, 1970 by Frances Hansen with the title "Turkey talk." That puzzle had 35 answers that never ever appeared in another puzzle and 6 more that only appeared in one other puzzle. Some theme answers: HOUSEOFTHESEVENGOBBLES GOBBLEDEGOOK GOBELINTAPESTRY GIGGLEGABBLEGOBBLEGIT MRSHEDDAGOBBLER GOLDENGOBLET ANTHEGOBBLEUNSLLGITYOU GOBBLEDPIE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/22/1970&g=36&d=A .....
LINT ROLLER - PAH!  Those are for sissies.
Just wanted to share my joy in getting 100 yellow stars in a row, having started doing NYT crosswords about 4 years ago! Hailing from Dalyan, a small resort town in the south of Turkiye 🤗

🧵A BUSYNESS or BUSINESS of ferrets I can get behind: I didn’t know that collective noun.
 • 
PAH as an exclamation… .  Let’s just say that was new to me, 😒!
 
————
✌🏽😉👋🏽

This one threw me to the point of getting it checked which is really rare. I was fine except for the SW corner. 

- CIPRO (ciprofloxacin) is also known as Ciplox. I didn't realise the R/O spelling difference between the generic and the brand and went with CIPLO. 

- For 'didn't get broken' HELD NERVE fit. 

- Together the L/N errors made the 'evening out' answer CLEANED - which makes perfect sense as something that has been cleaned is ready to wear for an evening out. 

Very tricky.
It appears that an earlier comment of mine has been removed. I would like to apologize if my comment was offensive to anyone. It was never my intention.
Great puzzle, lots of fun wordplay, takes in the trash was particularly good.

Relatively smooth solve but I did start to teeter in the SE corner - but managed to stay on my feet. My enjoyment was inCREASED. 

Probably already commented but thought the clue for CIPRO might have needed an abbreviation signal?  My late father put himself in the hospital by taking that powerful antibiotic and not staying properly hydrated.  

Also wanted to comment on a great article by Deb today as well as Larry Snyder's comments about writing the clues first.   

Well done all.
“LEASER” sounds like a word someone would say if they didn’t know the correct word, “lessor.”
Great misdirects! Really enjoyed this one, especially after I found my mistake.

I totally appreciate Deb's ode to brevity in her column entry. It's something I struggle with in all my correspondence. Saying a complex thought in one word is an art.

"I am sorry to have made such a long speech, but I did not have time to write a shorter one".
- Winston Churchill
Well, at least this was better than yesterday's, but many of these clues seem off.

In need of an evening out. Duh! 

Puns are always the most elusive clues for me. I almost never get them until filling the down or across letter that shows me what I've been missing
"In need of an evening out" is a great clue!

Today I learned that a group of Ferrets is called a "Business of Ferrets".
Love it.
It's right up there with a" Parliament of Owls".

Or a "Colony of Weasels" which in todays puzzle coincidently crosses the "Business of Ferrets"
Good Friday. A lot of tricky clues (some of which I still don’t understand) but was able to suss them out with crosses.
I was making record time and then sat in the SE corner for quite a while, foiled by “evening.” 🤦🏼‍♀️ Clever cluing, and a fun puzzle, thank you!!
I remain baffled by 15A and 36D. Some of the comments above enlightened me re 22A.

"In need of an evening out?" for CREASED, "Takes in the trash?" for DELETEDSCENES, and "The works?" for OEUVRE were very clever. So was "Problem for someone who's pushing 90, say" for SPEEDGUN, though "radar gun" seems more familiar to me.

Found this one moderately challenging and fun to solve. Took me about five minutes less than my Friday average.

One more late puzzle find. I actually thought about the possibility of the first theme answer in this one and was surprised to see that it had appeared. Anyway - a Wednesday from December 24, 2014 by Adam G. Perl. Those theme clues and answers in order: "1955 Julie London hit" CRYMEARIVER "Glide, in a way" PARASAIL "Intermediary" GOBETWEEN and then... "11- or 12-year-old Mongolian desert dweller?" GOBITWEEN "Left Bank quaff?" PARISALE "Certain waterway to the Black Sea?" CRIMEARIVER Here's the link to that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/24/2014&g=62&d=A ....
I was never going to solve a crossword with "held serve" as an answer, so I don't feel so bad about today.

Here to say that 49A is a great clue!!!!
“In need of an evening out?” Love it.
Tough challenge. Very clever
Great clues...esp loved 49 across...LOL!! Excellent Friday challenge, Larry...grazie!

I was fairly confident in PONDER, CREASED, and GROUPED, but the OEU___ in 44D couldn’t possible have been right, so I eventually gave up. 

Never would figured out OEUVRE or HELDSERVE, but I enjoyed the rest of the puzzle!

While I got it immediately, I've never heard anyone refer to programming in Java as "making some Java".

The southeast was the last to fall for me, thanks to some lovely and tricky cluing on CREASED and HELDSERVE.

I usually click through the first few across clues, and the first one I filled in was FERRETS (I have them as pets so I knew that a group of them is a business) and then the intersecting down answer was WEASELED - and there was no mention of this play on words in the puzzle info

One more puzzle. Never seen another like this; it was all in the clues, each of which was just one word. I'll just list the answers and see if you can guess the clues. ROWINGIMPLEMENT WORDOFCHOICE OPPOSITEOFNEATH BRUINSLEGEND MINERSDISCOVERY Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/10/2006&g=51&d=A .....
Excellent puzzle with only two proper names and no niche cultural signifiers.

Wasted some time with the clue ‘Made some Java…’ by thinking of words about volcanic eruptions. 

Today’s crossword really puts the cross in the word; I was constantly switching between across clues and down clues trying to eke out any letter that would help jog the synonymnemonic synapses.

1:04:45, 9:49 slower than my average. BUT for some reason this did not feel difficult and at every point felt within reach! That’s pure constructor skill, that is. Or just plain dumb luck. Anyhooo…. . That’s a proper Chidi argument for fans of the show.

Had HELDNERVE for a while before I fixed it. Crafty, crafty. Had a chuckle at Java, my kind of misdirect.

I was thinking stains on the carpet long before I imagined dog hair. ALONETIME was such a tease! Nice.

Finally fixed ABC to get the music.

This one was a great themeless. Great fill and wonderful cluing.
Nice puzzle! BUT I finished in 31:28 (timer stopped) BUT the app on computer still indicates RESUME and never updates my time stats?
Very clever! Well done! Fun solve.
You sure the trump EPA is measuring AQI in 2025?

Fun Friday with lots of clever clues today!  The word that caused my brow to furrow was PAH as it was unfamiliar to me beyond an utterance of exasperation. Maybe more of a regional use or entertainment I've been missing?!
More like this one, please! I enjoyed the wordplay, it required some thinking - CREASED, for example.  And there was no reliance on silly trivia.  Bravo!
Some diabolical clues today. I really wanted to put DELETEDTWEETS for 33A.
The fridayest Friday to friday in a while. Thoroughly enjoyable, and 3:14 (🥧?) under my average.

Coincidentally, I just dropped my daughter off at our local comic con to display her INNERGEEK! Loved that clue. 
I have a thing for collective nouns (and sometimes making them up) but did not know that FERRETS make a business! Love that!! I'm picturing them having a serious meeting in bowties.
Fun clues. I had DELETEDemailS first, and was stumped on CREASED. Well done!

Well, wheelhouses are apparently lining up for many of you.

For me, not so much. So the "trivia" plus the diabolical clueing made this a hard won puzzle.

Almost not complaining, as it was a real work out. Took 1h 26m to complete unaided.

I'm actually surprised i got the gold star.

Very disappointed there were no rebus or other tricks!

;)

(We're allowed to do this now right?)
Another 🙌 for 49 Across!
I impressed myself with this one.

Now THIS is a crossword. Not easy by any measure, but brilliantly clever clueing that allows any solver to get there with enough grit and crossing. 

What a joy.
Deb, what a lovely micro-essay on the value of brevity. I only wish I’d finished today’s puzzle in time say so earlier.
Tough, but fair! Had to leave and come back a couple times, and I confess I needed the column tip on "evening out," but otherwise a very satisfying finish.

Fun solve!

But “leaser” does not sit well with me as an answer

A beautiful mind! What a puzzle. For me, anyhow, I felt like every clue and every letter in the answers was sweated over! 

Beautiful work!!

Pronunciation can sometimes be so critical. 49 across is the one that got me. Even long after I had solved the entire puzzle, I was Googling whether “creased” was some sort of slang for tired or frazzled, and thus in need of an evening out (the main things I found involved someone making you laugh). I had no idea until I read this article that it was “evening” prounounced ee-ve-ning (as in the gerund form of “to even”) rather than eev-ning 🤦🏻‍♂️

Also have to add:
Clue for HATE WATCH = brilliant
PAH= gibberish. No one says that. ever. 



(this was meant to be a reply to my previous comment, which has yet to be posted, and has presumably become emu fodder)

Raced through this one. Surprising as the answers didn’t come easily. Guess I’m just in the zone today.
Currently overlooking the Irish Sea as we’re in Liverpool for a wedding today. I can see Blackpool tower in the distance. If I squint with one eye and ignore the freezing east wind I can imagine it’s the Tour Eiffel.  Almost.
Toodles.

I will post again, as my previous memo got EMU'd, but EENIE soured an otherwise clever and appropriately challenging Friday solve. The racist origins of the rhyme have been discussed ad nauseum in these comments in the past and there is no place for the word here.

Do better NYT. Stop reminding people of their generational trauma.
Too clever by half. Clueing was pretty iffy on this one
Wow thanks for a nice easy Friday after a Thursday that took me about three days to finish!
Was stuck on CREASED and HELD SERVE… what da ferk

@Barry Ancona

It's CHILL

Francis,

It's a good thing SWILL wasn't an entry in yesterday's puzzle (which I found CHIC).

@Barry Ancona
Or as Mr Porter would have said, Thou swill, thou witty...
@Barry Ancona No, LEASER owns the thing and LESSEE  pays money for it. The clue is "One receiving monthly payments", not one making.

Isabeau,

We have a problem here. The 5D clue in the Newspaper Version PDF is [One making monthly payments].
And I've always seen lessor and lessee in leases, never LEASER.

Deb,

Sorry. You are correct about the meaning of LEASER. The paper has an incorrect clue.

Francis,

After Isabeau posted, I looked at the online version and saw the variance. Changes from print to online happen from time to time, more often with Sundays, since The Magazine is printed mid-week and there is more time for second guessing.

@Barry Ancona

Interesting!
Thanks, @Barry. I’ve reported it.
@Barry Ancona Oh that's annoying! But a good explanation for the confusion.

@Barry Ancona

The lawyer in me struggled with this one.  I finally just had to trust the crosses.

Marshall Walthew,

No lawyer in me, but I had been reviewing a lease modification earlier in the day.

@Marshall Walthew

I solved in the app, so I had the corrected clue. But the lawyer in me immediately put LEsSoR and was annoyed when I had to take it out.

@Barry Ancona

Wait, what?  I think you are older than I am.

@Becky

In tennis, a player is expected to win most of the games he or she serves.  When the opposing player wins, it's called a break.  The number of breaks in a set usually determines who wins the set.  That's why traditionally, one has to win a set by two games.  (Nowadays, a tiebreaker is usually played, in which the serve is split evenly.  The tiebreaker only has to be won by two points.)

Here's the beginning of the Wikipedia article.


The 2001 anthrax attacks, also known as Amerithrax (a portmanteau of "America" and "anthrax", from its FBI case name),[1] occurred in the United States over the course of several weeks beginning on September 18, 2001, one week after the September 11 attacks. Letters containing anthrax spores were mailed to several news media offices and to senators Tom Daschle and Patrick Leahy, killing five people and infecting seventeen others. Capitol police officers and staffers working for Senator Russ Feingold were exposed as well.

@Eric Hougland

Oh, I'd have loved to lived in the corner of Colorado you know.

But, see, it's actually a little different for me.  The Colorado of my youth was ancient compared to the Colorado today.

I remember on a trip with my parents through the Rockies seeing strange people sliding down the mountain with boards on each foot.  We stopped to watch them.

I recall when Breckenridge was truly little more than a mountain town with a ski area near by.  Where you could get bite by stray dogs. I was almost 20 by that time.

And when I applied for college, the University of Colorado at Boulder replied that their non-resident quota for the year had already been met.

"Non-resident quota".  I lived in Pueblo, COLORADO.

So I lived for four more years in Colorado, going to the college in my home town, and eventually leaving Colorado forever to go to grad school at Stanford.  I never even applied to the University of Colorado at Boulder.

So I contend I am an exile from Colorado--the state found me undesirable, and so when I left I left for good.  And with less nostalgia than what might have been.

But it is really, really beautiful.  I often watch you tubes of people driving through Colorado, and am as in love with the beauty of the mountains as ever.

I just wish I felt at home there.

@Francis Seattle has quickly become my next favorite place to Maine and Vermont. Minnesota, honestly, was a possibility when I first graduated from art school. But I need the ocean. And some mountains. Will definitely visit, though!

I've done thousands of cryptic clues and I didn't get that clue. I'm not a fan of this misdirect. If you /had/ to use "evening" to mean AVENGERS I'd expect a fairer clue: "Evening actors in TV programme".

Cryptic crosswords always have two separate parts leading to the answer, in this case:
1. Some evening: AVENGERS are people who are getting even 
2. TV programme: AVENGERS was a TV programme
@Andrzej I’m sorry. Didn’t mean to offend. Mostly me just remembering a fun show from my youth.

@Mean Old Lady

Not only do ferrets actually get together in groups but, as I learned today, those groups are actually called "a business." Isn't that great?

From Google:
The Book of St. Albans, published in 1486, listed "besynes" as the proper term for a group of ferrets, and over time, this Middle English word transformed into the modern "business." This name aptly captures the nature of ferrets, known for their active and playful behavior.

@Cat Lady Margaret three cats in this household and I wear the cat hairs proudly…somebody once asked: what makes you think it’s okay for you to wear black? PAH!

@Cat Lady Margaret
I always had one on hand for foolish guests who wore black clothes (or, to be honest, any other color of clothes) when they came to visit and carelessly sat down on our couch. Some really crazy people actually invited one or ours to sit in their lap. (Heavy purring was supposed to be the payoff.)

"Oh dear, look what's happened.  Here, let me help you."  

All stickiness on sheet after sheet of the roller paper instantly disappeared, but we felt we should make the gesture, and despite all the cat hair, everyone kept coming back and they loved our cats.

Were you working on the puzzle on two different devices without closing the app on one device before finishing on the other? If so, that can happen. But no worries if you look at The Crossword > Archives and see a gold star for today. You get credit for finishing it, if you finish it on one device with two devices open. Also if you close and reopen the app on both devices, that will normally show the puzzle as finished on both.
